author: Seth Lakso, Staff Writer
title: Wilson helps Penguins' win Sullivan's debut
text:
Wilson helps Penguins' win Sullivan's debut By Seth Lakso, Staff Writer Published: October 10, 2015 Sign Up Text Alerts | newsletter 
PROVIDENCE, R.I. — It certainly wasn’t how he would have scripted it, but the Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins escaped Providence with a 2-1 overtime win Friday their American Hockey League opener, which was also Mike Sullivan’s first game as the team’s head coach. 
It took two timely goals from Scott Wilson, some excellent work on the penalty kill, and the kind of performance that earned Matt Murray goaltender-of-the-year honors last season for the Penguins to send the 9,230 at the Dunkin’ Donuts Center home unhappy Friday. 
“It wasn’t pretty,” said Sullivan, who got his coaching start in Providence with the Bruins 13 years ago. “It’s nice to get the result, but we’ve got a long way to go.” 
The Penguins squandered a 1-0 lead with just less than two minutes remaining in regulation, but recovered thanks to Wilson’s second goal of the game, which came during 3-on-3 overtime. 
Wilson’s game-winner was set up moments before by a left-pad save made by Murray on a Bruins breakaway. Derrik Pouliot then corralled the puck and advanced it to Oskar Sundqvist, who raced down and found Wilson alone in front of the net. 
“As a goalie, I think you can have a huge impact on 3-on-3 if you’re able to make kind of a highlight-reel save at one end,” said Murray, who had 40 saves. “You can give your team a lot of momentum heading the other way, and that’s what happened tonight.” 
Sullivan said earlier in the week he’d wished his team had more time to work on its special teams. On Friday, eight Penguins penalties led to six Bruins power plays — all of which Wilkes-Barre/Scranton managed to kill off. 
“The upside was that we got a lot of practice at (our penalty kill),” Sullivan said. “I thought (the PK) got a lot better as the game went on, but we’ve got to do a better job with our discipline overall if we’re going to have success on a consistent basis.” 
Wilson netted the Pens’ first goal of the season in the second period when he took a feed in the slot from Conor Sheary, spun around, and flung it passed Zane McIntyre, who had 38 saves. 
It wasn’t until Providence’s 38th shot of the night that Murray proved to be human. 
Moments after turning away a shot by Providence’s Alexander Khokhachev, the puck found its way to rookie Frank Valtrano on the sideboards. Valtrano gathered it and sent it past Murray for the Bruins’ lone goal. 
“We just had to shake it off,” Wilson said. “Murray played great all game, so we knew that was probably the only one that was going to go in tonight.”
